metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Java Packages
Java Packages & API

A package in Java is used to group related classes. Think of it as a folder in a file directory . We use packages to avoid name conflicts, and to write a better maintainable code. Packages are divided into two categories:
content.html: A package in Java is used to group related classes. Think of it as a folder in a file directory. We use packages to avoid name conflicts, and to write a better maintainable code. Packages are divided into two categories:

content.text: Built-in Packages
The Java API is a library of prewritten classes, that are free to use, included in the Java Development Environment.
content.html: The Java API is a library of prewritten classes, that are free to use, included in the Java Development Environment.

content.text: The library contains components for managing input, database programming, and much much more. The complete list can be found at Oracles website: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/ .
content.html: The library contains components for managing input, database programming, and much much more. The complete list can be found at Oracles website: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/.

content.text: The library is divided into packages and classes . Meaning you can either import a single class (along with its methods and attributes), or a whole package that contain all the classes that belong to the specified package.
content.html: The library is divided into packages and classes. Meaning you can either import a single class (along with its methods and attributes), or a whole package that contain all the classes that belong to the specified package.

content.text: To use a class or a package from the library, you need to use the import keyword:
content.html: To use a class or a package from the library, you need to use the import keyword:

content.code:
import

package
.
name
.
Class
;

// Import a single class


import

package
.
name
.
*
;

// Import the whole package
content.code_html:
import package.name.Class;   // Import a single class
import package.name.*;   // Import the whole package

content.text: Import a Class
If you find a class you want to use, for example, the Scanner class, which is used to get user input , write the following code:
content.html: If you find a class you want to use, for example, the Scanner class, which is used to get user input, write the following code:

content.code_html: import java.util.Scanner;

content.text: In the example above, java.util is a package, while Scanner is a class of the java.util package.
content.html: In the example above, java.util is a package, while Scanner is a class of the java.util package.

content.text: To use the Scanner class, create an object of the class and use any of the available methods found in the Scanner class documentation. In our example, we will use the nextLine() method, which is used to read a complete line:
content.html: To use the Scanner class, create an object of the class and use any of the available methods found in the Scanner class documentation. In our example, we will use the nextLine() method, which is used to read a complete line:

content.code:
import

java
.
util
.
Scanner
;



class

MyClass

{


public

static

void

(

content.code_html:
import java.util.Scanner;

class MyClass {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Scanner myObj = new Scanner(System.in);
    System.out.println("Enter username");

    String userName = myObj.nextLine();
    System.out.println("Username is: " + userName);
  }
}

content.text: Import a Package

There are many packages to choose from. In the previous example, we used the Scanner class from the java.util package. This package also contains date and time facilities, random-number generator and other utility classes.
content.html: There are many packages to choose from. In the previous example, we used the Scanner class from the java.util package. This package also contains date and time facilities, random-number generator and other utility classes.

content.text: To import a whole package, end the sentence with an asterisk sign ( * ). The following example will import ALL the classes in the java.util package:
content.html: To import a whole package, end the sentence with an asterisk sign (*). The following example will import ALL the classes in the java.util package:

content.code_html: import java.util.*;

content.text: User-defined Packages
To create your own package, you need to understand that Java uses a file system directory to store them. Just like folders on your computer:
content.html: To create your own package, you need to understand that Java uses a file system directory to store them. Just like folders on your computer:

content.code_html:
└── root
  └── mypack
    └── MyPackageClass.java

content.text: To create a package, use the package keyword:
content.html: To create a package, use the package keyword:

content.code_html:
package mypack;
class MyPackageClass {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    System.out.println("This is my package!");
  }
}

content.text: Save the file as MyPackageClass.java , and compile it:
content.html: Save the file as MyPackageClass.java, and compile it:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>javac MyPackageClass.java

content.text: Then compile the package:
content.html: Then compile the package:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>javac -d . MyPackageClass.java

content.text: This forces the compiler to create the "mypack" package.
content.html: This forces the compiler to create the "mypack" package.

content.text: The -d keyword specifies the destination for where to save the class file. You can use any directory name, like c:/user (windows), or, if you want to keep the package within the same directory, you can use the dot sign " . ", like in the example above.
content.html: The -d keyword specifies the destination for where to save the class file. You can use any directory name, like c:/user (windows), or, if you want to keep the package within the same directory, you can use the dot sign ".", like in the example above.

content.text: Note: The package name should be written in lower case to avoid conflict with class names.
content.html: Note: The package name should be written in lower case to avoid conflict with class names.

content.text: When we compiled the package in the example above, a new folder was created, called "mypack".
content.html: When we compiled the package in the example above, a new folder was created, called "mypack".

content.text: To run the MyPackageClass.java file, write the following:
content.html: To run the MyPackageClass.java file, write the following:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>java mypack.MyPackageClass

content.text: The output will be:
content.html: The output will be:

content.code_html: This is my package!

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
To use a class or a package from the Java API, which keyword should be used?
content.html: To use a class or a package from the Java API, which keyword should be used?
